thread.title_full: Party members reject SNP land reform plan

title: Party members reject SNP land reform plan
text:
SNP land reform proposal rejected by grassroots members Mure Dickie in Aberdeen ©Robert Harding Picture Library Knoydart, Western Highlands 
Members of the Scottish National party issued a rare rebuke to their leaders when delegates to its autumn conference refused to endorse a land reform bill that many complain is not radical enough. 
The unusual vote to “remit back” for revision a resolution endorsing Scottish government plans for land reform will increase pressure on SNP ministers to toughen the draft bill and is likely to dismay landowners already concerned about its implications. 
Nicola Sturgeon, first minister and SNP leader, made “radical land reform” an early priority of her administration but many members say the draft legislation does not do enough to promote wider and more transparent ownership. More Gangmasters agency to gain extra powers 
“This bill is a good bill but it could be a better bill,” Michael Russell, a former SNP cabinet member, told the conference. 
The vote by delegates to the conference in Aberdeen in effect requires party leaders to rethink the motion, which welcomed the introduction of the land reform bill. Speakers complained that the legislation did not do enough to challenge Scotland’s highly concentrated patterns of rural land ownership. 
Delegate Bill Middleton said he had voted for the motion to be remitted in the hope that it would push the government towards more radical controls on absentee landlords and wider opportunities for ownership of land by those who live on and work it. 
“I believe it’s Scotland’s land,” Mr Middleton said. 
Some members have been disappointed by the government’s decision not to seek a cap on the size of land holdings and its softening of requirements for public disclosure of all ownership. 
However, people involved in developing the legislation have warned that it must be carefully judged to reduce the risk of potential challenge by landowners under European human rights legislation. 
Mr Russell, MSP for Argyll and Bute and a former education secretary, said that such concerns were being given too much weight and that international rights laws and conventions could also be used to strengthen the rights of tenants and other groups. It’s encouraging that the grassroots are taking ownership of this issue 
- Andy Wightman, activist 
Andy Wightman, a prominent activist in land reform, said the vote offered a “clear mandate” for the SNP to strengthen the bill and make new reform commitments in its manifesto for next May’s Scottish parliamentary election. 
“It’s encouraging that the grassroots are taking ownership of this issue,” said Mr Wightman, who is a standing in May as a candidate for the Scottish Green party. 
SNP conferences have over the past decade been highly disciplined affairs, with motions crafted to maximise support rather than challenge the leadership. 
Party leaders sought to head off another potential revolt over the issue of unconventional gas extraction by announcing a government moratorium on underground coal gasification and widening a review into fracking. 
However, some delegates sought to remit back what they said was a weakly worded motion on the issue after a debate in which speakers were uniformly hostile to fracking and many said the ban on the technology should be made permanent. 
However, supporters of the motion said the moratoriums were steps in the right direction and an effort to remit the motion back for revision was defeated by 554 votes to 427.
